question: Sheriff Wyner... Afternoon, Miz Munson.
answer: Afternoon, Sheriff. You know the Funthes boy?

question: ...Mackatee Funthes?
answer: No no, WeeMack! Mackatee's eldest!

question: Oh yeah, believe I do.
answer: Well, he's a good boy but he done gone down to the Costco in Pascagoula and got hisself a blastah -- and he been playin' that music!

question: Uh-huh...
answer: Loud!

question: Well--
answer: "Left my wallet in El Segundo!"

question: He--
answer: Songs like that!

question: Uh-huh...
answer: Hippity-hop music!

question: I could--
answer: You know they call it hippity-hop music, but it don't make me wanna go hippity-hop!

question: No ma'am--
answer: And Othar don't like that music neither!

question: It's been disturbin' Othar then, has it?
answer: How could it help but do! That kind of music! You know what they call colored folks in them songs? Have you got any idea?

question: I don't think I--
answer: NIGGAZ! I don't wanna say the word. I won't say it twice, I'll tell you that. I say it one time.

question: Yes ma'am.
answer: In the course a swearin' out my complaint.

question: Yes'm--
answer: NIGGAZ! Two thousand years after Jesus! Thirty years after Martin Luther King! The age of Montel! Sweet lord a-mercy, izzat where we at?

question: Mm-mm--
answer: WeeMack down to Pascagoula buyin' a big thumpy stereo player?! So he can listen to that word in the house next to mine? Sheriff, you gotta help that boy!

question: Help him?
answer: You gotta take an innarest! EXTEND that helpin' hand!

question: Well, we're here to help...
answer: Well God bless ya. Don't wanna be tried and found wantin'.

question: No ma'am.
answer: Many many tunkalow parzen, Sheriff Wyner. Many many tunkalow parzen!

question: Many what ma'am?
answer: You have been tried and found wanting. Don't want that writin' on the wall!

question: No ma'am--
answer: Feast a Balthazar!

question: Mm-hm.
answer: John The Apostle said

question: Yes ma'am.
answer: He's a good man. Just needs instruction. Dog, you in peoples' way. You need somethin' to eat, Angel? Mm... gizzards...

question: He's a good man. Just needs instruction. Dog, you in peoples' way. You need somethin' to eat, Angel? Mm... gizzards...
answer: Above the fireplace is an oil portrait of a serious-looking black man of late middle-age with a neatly groomed mustache starting to gray. A couple of candles sit on the mantel below the portrait, giving it the semblance of a shrine.
speaker2: INT. MUNSON HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT

question: Othar, I went'n complained about WeeMack, I hope it'll do some good. That boy hangin' by a thread! Over the pit! Fiery pit! "I Left My Wallet in El Segundo"! ...Sixty-seven years of life, forty- six years of marriage, you mean to tell me you never one time suffered from piles? It's the human condition, most humans anyway. Like that ball player said ...Passed on before you got piles. Mmmmhmm. Thank the Lord you wasn't sick. You don't wanna sicken 'n die. No, you wanna pass nice 'n peaceful... go to sleep one night, wake up in the glory land... woof... ...Well who's that now, Pickles?
answer: The candles below the portrait of Othar go out, sending up thin wisps of smoke.
speaker2: INT. MUNSON HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT

question: PICKLES!
answer: Ma'am?

question: Go get 'im!
answer: I do beg your pardon?

question: Go get Pickles, I didn't let 'im out!
answer: Pickles...

question: Oh, he's up the tree again. Your gonna have to shimmy on up.
answer: I am so terribly sorry, madam. But won't the feline eventually tire of his lonely perch and, pining for his master's affection, return on his own initiative?

question: Huh? No, he won't come down less you fetch him. He'd set there til Gabriel blows his horn if someone didn't shimmy up. Up with you now!
answer: Well then couldn't we perhaps offer him kitty treats and enticements, or if not foodstuffs perhaps squeaky little toys of the kind formerly manufactured in Hong Kong but now produced in the other so-called "Little Tigers"... ...of the Pacific Rim? The point bein', do we have to actually ascend the tree--

question: Look, I don't want no doubletalk. If you ain't gonna fetch him down I guess I gotta call the po-lice...
answer: Police...

question: They ain't gonna be happy. Every time they come fetch him down they swear they won't do it no more...
answer: No need to call the authorities. I did this often as a youth -- why, I was a positive lemur... Here, kitty...

question: Don't upset him, now!
answer: I wouldn't dream of it... harmless little felix domesticus... Come to

question: I thank you, madam, for your act of kindness.
answer: Well you let him out.

question: I certainly did and I do apologize no end. Allow me to present myself, uh, formally
answer: What, like Elmer?

question: Beg your pardon, ma'am?
answer: Fudd?

question: No no, Ph.D. is a mark of academic attainment. It is a degree of higher learning bestowed, in my case, in recognition of my mastery of the antique languages of Latin and Greek. I also hold a number of other advanced degrees including the baccalaureate from a school in Paris, France, called the Sorbonne.
answer: Sore bone, well I guess that's appropriate. You ever study at Bob Jones University?

question: I have not had that privilege.
answer: It's a bible school, only the finest in the country. I send them five dollars every month.

question: That's very gener--
answer: I'm on their mailing list. I'm an Angel.

question: Indeed.
answer: They list my name in the newsletter, every issue. I got the literature here, you wanna examine it.

question: Perhaps when my head has recovered from its... buffeting. Mrs. Munson, are you at all curious as to why I darkened your door, as the expression has it, on this lovely camelia-scented morn?
answer: I was wondering, til you let Pickles out. Then in all the excitement--

question: I quite understand. The fact is that I saw the sign on your window advertising a room to let, and it is the only such sign among the houses of this charming, charming street.
answer: Yeah, I got a room. I'm lookin' for a quiet tenant. Fifteen dollars a week

question: I quite understand. Madam, you are addressing a man who is quiet -- and yet not quiet, if I may offer a riddle... ...Perhaps you can show me the room, Mrs. Munson, and allow me to explain.
answer: Well you can see the room, but I don't like double-talk.

question: You see, madam, I am currently on sabbatical from the institution where I teach -- the University of Mississippi at Hattiesburg. I am taking a year off to indulge my passion -- I don't believe that is too strong a word -- for the music of the Renaissance. I perform in -- and have the honor of directing -- a period instrument ensemble that performs at Renaissance fairs and other cultural fora... ...thoo-out central and southern Mississippi. We perform on the instruments for which the music was originally composed, in the belief that... that... Why, this is lovely...
answer: Wait a minute. You got some kind of band?

question: The word "band" would be, in this context, something of an anachronism. Though we do play together -- hence the word "ensemble" -- the nature of the music is such that one would hesitate to apply the epithet "band" with its connotations of jangling rhythm and ear-popping amplification.
answer: So you don't play hippity-hop, "I Left My Wallet in El Segundo," songs with the titles spelt all funny?

question: Madam, I shudder. I quake. The revulsion I feel for modern popular music, and all other manifestations of contemporary decay, is, I have no doubt, the equal of y'own. Why, we play music that was composed to the greater glory of God. Devotional music. Church music.
answer: Gospel music?

question: Well-inspired by the gospels, certainly. The vintage, of course, is no more recent than the Rococo.
answer: Rococo, huh? Well, I guess that'd be okay.

question: Yes, yes, yes, this looks promising...
answer: Little dank, ain't it?

question: Oh, indeed, but that only improves the acoustics... ...Marvelous. These earthen walls are ideal for baffling the higher registers of the, uh, lute and, uh, sackbutt. That's why so much music of the cinquecento was played in crypts and catacombs. Yes, this will do nicely... ...This is perfect. This is more than perfect. I can scarcely contain my glee.
answer: You containing it okay.

question: Allow me to pay you a week in advance. Allow me to pay you two weeks in advance. Allow me to pay you a month in advance. I cannot countenance the thought of these charming apartments being tenanted by someone unappreciative of their special je ne sais quoi.
answer: That would be a shame.

question: ...You wouldn't believe this shit, sometimes even out here on the casino floor you gonna find sanitary napkin shit stuck there, Tucks, I don't know what the fuck people do while they're gambling here man.
answer: I ain't peelin' funky shit with my human hands, man. That's a prescription for disease and viruses and shit, attackin' y'insides.

question: You gotta do it. Mr. Gudge checks everything. Man is a motherfuck. Shit -- looka this. ...You keep an eye out, man. I found a hundred-dollar chip once.
answer: Fuck that, man. I ain't pawin' through used Tucks for a fi' dollar chip.

question: I said it was a hundred.
answer: Man, your guts gonna turn to soup'n leak outcha fuckin' asshole.

question: One, Mountain! ...Scrub two! Scrub three! Four, Mountain!
answer: Cut, goddamnit. His canteen fell off. ...Props! ...The goddamn thing's canteen fell off. It would have been a good take.

question: Okay. Okay. We're prepared for that... ... Mountain, bring Otto with the apparatus.
answer: What the hell is this?

question: World War I vintage gas mask. It's authentic. Strapped on, of course, so it can't fall off. The animal is free to be as active as he wants, doesn't inhibit his movement, and I think it really sells the whole doughboy thing--
answer: It looks like a fucking joke.

question: ...Nnnnrnff!
answer: What?

question: No, nothing, uh... you're absolutely right, the gas mask is a whimsical concept--
answer: How the hell does it eat when it gets to the Kennel Rations?

question: Well, you're absolutely right-
answer: Don't let the client see this.

question: Of course not, that would be inappropriate--
answer: Or the Humane fucker.

question: No no--
answer: They'll shut the fucking spot down, Pancake. Put the goddamn canteen back on. That says he's a soldier. Dented tin canteen. Just tie the damn thing to his collar.

question: Easiest thing in the world. I just thought -- but the canteen is much better. Good concept. Let's go with that--
answer: What's he doing?

question: Well, he's uh... Just breathe normally, Otto.
answer: The fucking dog can't breathe.

question: Oh, he can breathe, that thing is -- just breathe normally, Otto.
answer: The fucking dog cannot breathe! Get that fucking thing off him!

question: Of course. Easiest thing in the world. ...It's on good and tight, I, uh... Just breathe normally, Otto.
answer: Get the fucking thing off him!

question: Don't have my Leatherman. Mountain! Give me your Leatherman! Chop chop!
answer: Get the fucking thing off him! Chitra, make sure the Humane fucker doesn't come over here! Bring him to craft services!

question: Good idea! Ice water, treats-
answer: Not the dog, you idiot! The Humane fucker! Distract him!

question: Right! Of course!
answer: Oh my god, he's bleeding!

question: No, that's me -- I -- the Leatherman... here we go.
answer: Put up a couple solids here -- I don't want the client seeing this!

question: Come on, Otto!
answer: Otto is fucking dead!

question: I know you all remember that when Moses came down the mountain, carrying the word a God, come down that Sinai peak, he caught those Israelites red- handed. What he catch 'em doin'? He caught 'em worshipping a golden calf. ...He caught 'em with their backs turned on God! ...He caught 'em worshipping a FALSE God! A God of EARTHLY things! He caught them Israelites in DECLINE! ...Because backslidin' is DECLINE, brothers and sisters! You hear talk these days, and I know you've heard this talk, you hear talk of DECLINE, well all that means is we done turned our back on God! ...People say civilization doin' this, civilization doin' that, civilization in DECLINE! Well it ain't no civilization! It ain't no them! It's US, brothers and sisters! ...It's what's in our hearts, each and every one of us when we like them Israelites! Slidin' awa-a-a-ay down that Godly slope, slippin' and slidin' toward the mire and muck a the stinkhole of greed -- that's DECLINE! ...And what did Moses do when he saw those declinin' backslidin' never- mindin' sinners? ...Moses SMOTE those sinners in his wrath yes he did! ...Y'all know what smote is! I smite! You smite! He smites! We done smote! ...To smite is to go UPSIDE the head! ...Because sometimes, brothers and sisters, that is the ONLY way! ...To smite is to reMIND! We got to STOP that decline! And scramble back UP to the face a the almighty Gyod! ...'Stead a worshippin' that GOLDEN calf, that earthly TRASH on that GARBAGE island! That GARBAGE island in that shadowland WAY outside the Kingdom a God! ...That GARBAGE island where scavenger birds feast on the bones a the backslidin' damned! ...And so, let us pray... Why thank you, Sister Rose.
answer: That man has a lot to say. And every word of it the truth.

question: Oh now ladies...
answer: Stout, too.

question: Oh now you gracious ladies.
answer: It was a good sermon. That man has a lot to say.

question: And the choir was all in good voice. Mm-mm- ...Who could that--
answer: My dear Mrs. Munson, I do so hope this is not an inopportune time for our first practice--

question: Somebody die?
answer: I beg your-- Oh! ...No no, no bereavement, though it is so kind of you to enquire. No, the hearse is simply a vehicle commodious enough to accommodate all of the members of our ensemble. And of course our instruments, contrived in an age ignorant of miniaturization... ...Let me introduce you to my friends, my colleagues, these devoted and passionate musicians... This is Gawain MacSam, our bassoonist... ...General Nguyen Pham Doc, viola da gamba...

question: What do you think, General? Present any problems? ...Good then. ...All right, gentlemen, why don't we all crowd around and go over the plan. ...This, gentlemen, is the Lady Luck, gambling den, cash cow, Sodom of the Mississippi delta -- and the focus of our little exercise. Here is Orchard Street... ...and here is the residence of Marva Munson, the charming lady whom y'all met moments ago. Gentlemen... ...You... are... here. Now. This brings us to this square... ...Gentlemen, I believe you are all aware that the Solons of the State of Mississippi, to wit, its legislature, have decreed that no gaming establishment shall be erected within its borders upon dry land. They may, however, legally float upon any watercourse defining a state boundary. But while the gambling activity itself is restricted to riverboats, no such restriction applies to the functions ancillary to this cash besotted bidnis. The casino's offices, locker rooms, facilities to cook and clean, and most importantly its counting houses- the reinforced, secret, and super secure repositories of the lucre -- may all be situated... wherever. Gawain -- where is wherever?
answer: Say wha?

question: Where is the money?
answer: Oh. End of every shift pit boss brings the cash down to the hold of the ship in the locked cash box; once a day all the cash boxes're moved to the counting room.

question: And where is the counting room?
answer: Well, uh... in that square there. Where you pointing.

question: And what, to flog a horse that if not at this point dead is in mortal danger of expirin', does the dotted square represent?
answer: ...Offices. Underground.

question: And this brings us to Lump. To look at Lump you might wonder, what function could he possibly fill, what specialized expertise could he possibly offer, to our merry little ol' band a miscreants. Well gentlemen, in a project of such magnitude and such risks, it is traditional -- nay, it is imperative -- to enlist the services of a hooligan, a goon, an ape, a physical brute, who will be our security, our fist, our batterin' ram. Lump is our blunt instrument, and on all our behalfs I wish him a warm Mississippi welcome.
answer: Thanks, Professor.

question: Well gentlemen, here you are, men of different backgrounds and differing talents, men with, in fact only two things in common
answer: There's no "I" in "team".

question: You mind! I don't want that kind of talk in my home, even in the root cellar. This is a Christian house, boy, none of that hippity-hop language.
answer: Sadly, Gawain is given to--

question: Sometimes it's the only way! ...I'm tryin' to help you, son! ...Better yaself!
answer: As well you should, ma'am. But Gawain at times is so far transported by his love of the music of the early Renaissance as to--

question: Don't make no never-mind he's transported!
answer: I understand your--

question: You been smokin'?
answer: Certainly not, madam. I understand your indignation. And I was offering explanation, not excuse. I myself am offended by those who cannot find the proper words to express themselves and have recourse to--

question: Yes, yes... ...A fiery lad! But then Youth is fiery! A fact often remarked upon by the poets of the Romantic era.
answer: My youth I was in church, I wasn't walkin' around fiery. Youth ain't no excuse for nothin'! Well, anyway... only came down to show you the fife. ...Othar's fife. He burned his own.

question: ...Did he?
answer: Mm-hm. I thought maybe bein' a musical man you'd be interested.

question: Oh, I am indeed--
answer: Cut it himself and burned the holes. Israelites called it a kalil.

question: Ah.
answer: Kalil, fife, same thing. You can read about it in the Bible. Ain't nothin' new under the sun.

question: Indeed not.
answer: Gone these twenty years. He was some kind of man. ...Blowed the kalil.

question: ...I don't suppose Othar ever turned his hand -- or, uh, heh-heh-heh, turned his lip -- to the shofar? ...The ceremonial ram's horn, sounded by the priests of the Hebrews?
answer: I don't know nothin' 'bout that. Othar didn't study no shofar, to the extent a my knowledge. The kalil was good enough for my Othar... ...Some kind of man.

question: Hey baby, don't be cruel. Jus' sneak one little peek... ...Don't let this uniform fool ya-- You don't need to be gamblin', honey, you lookin' at a sure thing. They call me Mr. 21, baby, 'cause that's how I measure up. I am the original black Jack, honey, accept no substitutions. You can pull my lever all day long, sweet mama, I ain't never gonna come up lemons. That's right, sugar, you can blow on my dice any ol' time. But Mr. Gudge, she had an ass that could pull a bus. This lady was fine, fine, dandy, divine.
answer: I don't care how big her ass was, MacSam. You're fired.

question: Say what?
answer: There is no fraternizing with customers on the Lady Luck. Clean out your locker.

question: But Gudge-
answer: Get out of here. You're fired.

question: You can't fire me. I sue your ass!
answer: Sue me? For what?

question: Sue you for fuckin' punitive damages, man!
answer: Punitive damages.

question: Ya damn skippy. I know you firin' my ass 'cause I'm black!
answer: Everyone on the custodial staff is black, MacSam. Your replacement's gonna be black. His replacement will no doubt be black.

question: Shit, man, it ain't about apologizin'! He fired me 'cause I'm black!
answer: He can't do that. You could sue him. Open and shut case.

question: Fuckin' A.
answer: This is not 1952.

question: Oh, we can get through the rock, no worries there. Simplest thing in the world. Why we blow right through it; I've got a pyro license, we bore a hole in the rock, pack in a little plastique; igneous blows pretty good, and we--
answer: Is he gonna want a piece of the action?

question: ...Who?
answer: ...Igneous?

question: Of course. I understand that. But this is Mountain... ...I don't keep secrets from Mountain. That's not how you maintain a loving, caring relationship.
answer: ...You brought your bitch to the waffle house? ...Man brings his bitch to the waffle house!

question: Look, you, I'll thank you to stop referring to Mountain that way. She's the other half of my life.
answer: Everybody lookin' at me like I'm a fuck-up, losin' that sorry-ass job, and this motherfucker bring his bitch to the waffle house!

question: You son of a bitch punk! Shut your goddamn mouth!
answer: Come and get me motherfuck! Come on, baby, let's get it on!

question: Little punk. I got syrup on my safari jacket.
answer: Gentlemen, I propose that we consider the matter of this woman, Mountain Water, to be--

question: Mountain Girl.
answer: I am so very sorry. I propose that we consider this matter to be closed, and we shall chose to trust her, since we now have no choice, and since she shall share only in Mr. Pancake's portion of the booty.

question: ...You just a readin' fool, ain't you Mr. Dorr.
answer: Yes yes, I must confess, madam, that often I feel more at home in these ancient volumes than I do in the hustle-bustle of our modern world. To me, paradoxically, the literature of the so-called "dead tongues" has more currency than this mornin's newspaper.

question: Mm-mm.
answer: In these books... ...In these volumes, there is the accum'lated wisdom a mankind which succours me when the day is hard or the night lonely and long.

question: Wisdom of mankind, what about the wisdom of the Lord?
answer: Oh yes, the Good Book, mm. I have found reward in its pages. But for me there are other good books as well; the heavy volumes of Antiquity, freighted with the insights of Man's glorious age. And then of course I love, love, love the works of Mr. Ed G'Allan Poe.

question: I know who he is. Kinda creepy.
answer: Oh no, madam, noooo. Not of this world, true; he lived in a dream, an ancient dream... "Helen, they beauty is to me Like those Nicean barks a yore That gently, o'er a perfumed sea, The weary, wayworn wanderer bore To his own native shore... "

question: Who was Helen? She wasn't a loose woman, was she? Some kinda whore a Babylon?
answer: One doesn't know who Helen was, though I picture her as bein' very, very extremely... pale. ...Miz Munson, I was tryin' to think of some way of expressin' my gratitude to you for takin' in... ...this weary, wayworn wanderer... ...It's just a modest little ol' present, why it's practically nothing at all.

question: Oh Mr. Dorr, why you are such a gallant man...
answer: Oh no madam, I blush. I melt. No, I just happened to hear of this gospel concert tomorrow night, The Mighty Mighty Clouds of Joy, and I thought you and a friend from church, perhaps...

question: Othar loved that music... Yes, I got a widow-lady friend...
answer: The concert is up in Memphis, but I have arranged for a car service to transport you thither and, needless to say, back home at the concert's termination. My friends and I will be rehearsing here tomorrow evening so you needn't worry about the security of your charming little old house...

question: Evenin', Miz Munson, I just came by... ...to let you know I had a word with WeeMack. He says he gonna comply with your request, keep the music down and neighborly.
answer: Mm-hm.

question: So you have a pleasant evening now, and just let us know--
answer: Hang on there, Sheriff, somebody I want you to meet.

question: Ma'am, I'm a little pressed for time--
answer: Why, you chasin' a gang of bank robbers? Get on in here say hello.

question: ...We was just havin' tea, talkin' about Othar-- ...Hm... Bussed his own dishes. You can always tell a gentleman.
answer: Someone was here, ma'am?

question: Mm-hm, with me'n Othar.
answer: Well, maybe I'll catch him next time...

question: Come on up to his room. Mm, he's neat.
answer: Very neat.

question: Probably went down to the cellar to play with his friends.
answer: Ma'am, I really have to... ...be gettin' back...

question: What the hell is this?
answer: It's just my way of sayin', well, goddamnit, I don't know what it's like walkin' in your shoes, bein' all tightass and all, and you don't know what it's like to walk in my shoes, but, well... ...You know, there's the custodian, and then there's the man inside the custodian, y'understand what I'm sayin'... ...and that man has needs, dig, and I guess those needs, Mr. Gudge, which they usually involve women with big asses, well those motherfuckin' needs sometimes well up over the custodian like the motherfuckin' Johnstown Flood. But my point is it ain't gonna happen again. Not if it's humanly possible...

question: Hmm...
answer: But Jesus, if you'd seen the ass on that girl, Mr. Gudge, you'd a wanted her sitting on your face too.

question: Well, we're all human.
answer: Ya damn skippy.

question: No no, me and this gentleman here have to get square. Let me tell you something, MacSam. You wanna know something?
answer: I don't wanna know shit from you.

question: I'm gonna tell you how I came down to Mississippi. Wasn't born here, you know. I'm from Scranton, Pennsylvania... ...Nnnff!
answer: Huh?

question: ...Scranton, Pennsylvania. Came down here in 1964. Greyhound Bus. With the Freedom Riders. You know who the Freedom Riders were, MacSam?
answer: I don't give a shit who they were. Just tell me when they gonna leave.

question: The Freedom Riders, my fine young man, were a group of concerned liberals from up North -- whites, Negros, and yes, Jewish people -- all working together, just like we are here. Concerned citizens who came down here so that local black people could have their civil liberties. So that people like you could have the vote.
answer: ...You know what, man?

question: What, brother?
answer: I don't vote. So fuck you.

question: Why you fucking--
answer: And the bus you rode in on!

question: Yes, madam?
answer: My friend Mrs. Funthes is here so I'm about to go on out. I just wanted to leave y'all with some cinnamon cookies... ...Y'all sound pretty good. It'd be nice if you'd come by the church some day, give us a recital.

question: Oh madam, you are too kind. Our music, however, is -- how shall I put it? -- rather Roman in its outlook; many of our pieces were commissioned by the Holy See.
answer: Oh, I see all right, but we don't make a big whoop-dee-do about denominations; everybody welcome at our church. We've had Methodists come in. Episcopals. Even had a Jew come in once with a guitar back in the sixties.

question: ...why, it's nothing to make a fuss about. Perfectly all right... happens all the time...
answer: ...You gotta go find it, dipshit!

question: ...No, no. Really, I'm perfectly all right.
answer: Perfectly all right? You just blew your fucking finger off!

question: Sure, but--
answer: Well get back down there and find it, man! I ain't pickin' up your goddamn finger!

question: The General is even now exercising every effort to retrieve your mischievous little pet. Please go, go and enjoy your concert, and we shall see you later in the evening. Au revoir, mes dames! Despite our little setback we find ourselves on schedule to penetrate the vault... ...here, this afternoon, having successfully blasted that little ol' rock to pieces during Miz Munson's choir practice. ...Clark, perhaps you can run us through the game plan for what remains of our tunnelin'.
answer: Of course. Why, it's child's play now, easiest thing in the world. Only a couple of feet separate us from the vault... ...Just the usual spadework until we hit the masonry of the vault, and then we drill through.

question: And will you be able to wield the drill with your maimed extremity?
answer: Oh, I should think so, it's only one finger. Inhibits me in doing finer work, of course. I'll always have to live with that... Ahem. Maybe, and I'm just thinking out loud here, maybe since, as you say, it will present problems later...

question: Yes, Clark?
answer: Well, maybe -- and this is something I've talked over with Mountain Girl, and she agrees with me, so it's not just one person's opinion -- maybe I should get a little extra compensation for the accident. ...Somewhat larger share. Why, if this were any other line of work I'd be getting workmen's comp, wouldn't I? Might even have a pretty good lawsuit.

question: Well ain't that somethin'.
answer: Hnnnn. Arrunggggh! Rnffff. ...Mmmmnggh! ...IBS!

question: ...Say what?
answer: IBS! Irritable Bowel Syndrome! Is there a men's room down here?!

question: Oh man, you shouldn't be using the men's room--
answer: Or a lady's room! IBS! Quickly!

question: You shoulda shit back in the house, man! We don't want Elron finding you in the goddamn crapper!
answer: No choice! Quickly! It's a medical condition!

question: Charge should've gone off already.
answer: I do beg your pardon?

question: The charge to collapse the tunnel. I set it for eight minutes.
answer: Well that time, and more, has most certainly elapsed. I need not remind you of the importance of obliterating any trace of a connection between the vault and this house. It was of the essence of this plan that it should appear that the money had simply vanished. Without a trace. Spirited away, as it were, by ghosts.

question: Of course. I understand.
answer: The conundrum of the undisturbed yet empty vault, the unsolvable riddle of the sealed yet violated sanctum, is of the utmost importance not only to make our caper innelectually satisfying. It is also exigent as a matter of practical fact

question: She certainly does.
answer: Therefore -- to draw the unavoidable conclusion -- someone shall have to reenter the tunnel to reset that charge.

question: Hsst... Madam... ...Mrs. Munson, if I might have a word...
answer: You get back down those stairs!

question: I assure you I shall be--
answer: Hush! Down those stairs! We havin' tea now! I be down shortly. ...He's the tenant.

question: She shall be down shortly... ...Tea. Dainties.
answer: I don't know what you boys been up to but I wasn't born yesterday and I know mischief when I see it. Now I want an explanation, but first I want you boys to get your fannies up here with y'alls period instruments. I been tellin' the ladies about your music and they wanna hear you play. ...Hmph.

question: Goodbye, ladies. We had such a pleasant time.
answer: Now, I wanna know what's goin' on.

question: Yes indeed, and the thirst for knowledge is a very commendable thing. Though in this instance, I believe when you hear the explanation, you will laugh riotously, slappin' your knee and perhaps even wipin' away a giddy tear, relieved of your former concern.
answer: Hmph.

question: This don't smell right. I'm callin' Sheriff Wyner.
answer: Madam -- if you please. Yes! Yes! It was a lie! A fantastic tale! You have us! Dead to rights! But please allow me to tell you the truth -- in private. Madam... ...What I am about to reveal to you, you may find... shocking. Mrs. Munson, I must tell you that we are not... what we appear.

question: Mm-hm.
answer: We are not in fact musicians of the late Renaissance. Nor of the early or mid period. We are, in fact... criminals! Desperate men, madam! We have tunneled into the nearby offices of the Lady Luck gambling emporium and have relieved it of its treasure!

question: Lord have mercy!
answer: It is true that the Lady Luck is a den of iniquity, a painted harlot luring people into sin and exciting the vice of greed with her false promise of easy winnings. Oh, her gains are ill-gotten, yes, but I offer no excuses -- save one! We men have each pledged half of our share of the booty to a charitable institution -- the General, to a placement service for Southeast Asian refugees; Mr. Pancake to the Blue Ridge Parkway Conservancy; and Lump to the United Jewish Appeal. As compensation for use of your house we had planned to donate a full share to Bob Jones University, without burdening you with guilty knowledge by informing you of same. But you have wrested the information from me! Now it is all on the table. Now you have it, the whole story, the awful truth.

question: Stolen money!
answer: Yes, yes, shamefully I admit it, yes! But find the victim, Mrs. Munson, I challenge you! Even the casino itself, that riparian Gomorra, shall suffer no harm! It has an insurance company, a financial behemoth that will cheerfully replenish its depleted vaults! That is its function! And the insurance company itself is made up of tens and tens of thousands of policy-holders so that -- we have done the calculations, Mrs. Munson! -- so that at the end of the day, at the final reckoning, each policy- holder shall have contributed only one penny -- one single solitary cent -- to the satisfaction of this claim.

question: ...Just one penny?
answer: Think of it, Mrs. Munson! One cent from thousands upon thousands of people so that Bob Jones University can continue on its mission! Why, I have no doubt that, were the policy- holders aware of the existence of that august institution, why, each and every one of them would have volunteered some token amount to the furtherance of its aims!

question: Well that's prob'ly true...
answer: Yes madam, sadly, the criminal stain is upon my soul, but the benefit shall accrue to any number of worthy causes. As long, that is, as the secret stays with us. And I, surely, shall not be the one to divulge it.

question: Well... it's hard to see the harm in it... One penny... ...I'm sorry, Professor.
answer: Excuse me, ma'am?

question: No. It's wrong. Don't you be leadin' me into temptation.
answer: Madam, I must strenuously protest--

question: No, it's just plain wrong. Stealin'. I know your intentions were good, and I won't call the police if you give the money back. But I gotta see that you do it.
answer: Madam--

question: And all a you gotta go to church with me next Sunday.
answer: And... engage in divine worship?

question: I made up my mind. You can double- talk all you want, but its church or the county jail.
answer: But--

question: Motherfuck!
answer: Yes. Unfortunately, Mrs. Munson has rather complicated the situation--

question: I know how to discomplicate it! Put a cap in the old lady's head! Then everything simple again!
answer: ...Not easy to do. Many reasons. Practical ones

question: Well -- fuck, man! What we gonna do, give the money back and go to church?!
answer: I shudder. I quake. ...You sir, are a Buddhist. Is there not a middle way?

question: What you got there, Gawain?
answer: Why -- nothin', mama.

question: Nothin' my ass! You got a dog there!
answer: No, Mama!

question: A filthy noisy little pest of a puppy dog gonna shit all over the house!
answer: He won't shit in the house, Mama, I'm gonna train him, I promise, gonna train him real good--

question: I'm gonna train you real good! I told you don't bring no stray dogs into this house! ...You wait til your Daddy gets home, he gonna lay into you proper!
answer: Please don't hurt me no more! I love you, Mama!

question: Daddy gonna kick your ass! ...Bringin' in a filthy dirty dog!
answer: Please don't hurt me, Mama!

question: She just an old colored lady to you -- you do it, man!
answer: Why you sniveling little coward!

question: What you say, you whiney motherfucker? I come up your irritated ass with this -- motherfuckin' gun--
answer: You think you scare me, you mewling punk! You don't scare me! Bull Connor and all his dogs didn't scare me! ...Be a man!

question: You fuck!
answer: Be a man!

question: You ain't no fuckin' man, fuckin' a sixty-year-old lady in pigtails!
answer: WHY YOU BASTARD PUNK! MOUNTAIN GIRL IS FIFTY-THREE! ...SHE COULD RIDE YOUR ASS TO JELLY!

question: Well this is most irregular. We will need a Hefty bag. She is in the kitchen. I shall distract her while you steal out with the carcass. Well, my dear Mrs. Munson, I have outlined your position to my colleagues and I now return to you to return our collective verdict.
answer: Mm-hmm.

question: There was much spirited discussion and an atmosphere of frank give-and- take. Some of our number were initially appalled at your proposal that we simply return the money; some were more receptive.
answer: I don't care they was receptive or not!

question: And that attitude, madam, was a factor in our discussions. To a man, I must say, they were devastated at the prospect of not being able to contribute to their respective charities.
answer: Well that is a shame.

question: Indeed. But at the end of the day, your position prevailed, and the men have decided that we shall return the money -- every last cent of it! -- and attend Sunday services, rather than spend the remainder of our years wasting away in the Mississippi Men's Correctional Facility. Though that was the original preference of some.
answer: Well I'm glad y'all came to see the light, anyway. I'm gonna have some tea and go to bed.

question: ...T'was our at brought us to this pass...
answer: What, Professor?

question: Our overweening pride... The old woman is a more potent antagonist than one had imagined... ...Now, Lump, I'm afraid it falls to you to finish the job. ...The comedy must end.
answer: ...Professor, I been doing some thinking.

question: Oh dear. Oh dear oh dear oh dear.
answer: Maybe she's right! Maybe we should be going to church!

question: Oh dear, Lump. I feared that those would be your words. Not that I don't appreciate your giving the matter the benefit of your thought. But please recall, young man, our respective functions in this enterprise. I am a professor, the professor as you yourself so often say, the thinker, the "brains of the operation," trained in fact in the arts of cogitation. You, Lump, are the goon, the hooligan, the dumb brute whose actions must be directed by a higher intelligence.
answer: Yeah, I know, but--

question: No buts, dear boy! Do not repeat the error of thinking! Now is the moment of praxis! Now, my dear boy, you must act!
answer: I can't do it, Professor! A nice old lady like that!

question: Think of the riches, Lump, that you and I alone shall divide! Recall the dream of wealth untold that first drew you to this enterprise!
answer: But--

question: And reflect also that if you decline to act, forcing me to do so, then you shall no longer have any entitlement to the money! Your offices shall have been nugatory!
answer: You mean -- you mean -- you're gonna kill her?!

question: Of course! My hand would be forced!
answer: I can't let you do that, Professor! A nice old lady like that!

question: You?! Allow? Not allow? What presumption! You stupid boy! You very very extremely stupid boy!
answer: Oh yeah? ...Well who looks stupid now? ...Huh? ...No bullets?
